contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox nobility | name = Umberto I, Count of Savoy | image = Humbert I of Savoy tomb.jpg | image_size = 230px | caption = The cenotaph of Umberto I of Savoy in the Cathedral of [[Saint-Jean-de-Maurienne]] | noble family = [[House of Savoy]] | father = Amadeus, Count of Belley | mother = | spouse = Ancilla of Lenzburg | birth_date = {{circa|980}} | birth_place = | death_date = 1047 or 1048 | death_place = [[Hermillon]] | burial_place = Cathedral of [[Saint-Jean-de-Maurienne]] }} '''Umberto I''' ({{circa|980}}–1047/1048) (in French, ''Humbert aux blanches-mains''; in Italian, ''Umberto Biancamano'') was the first [[Count of Savoy]] from 1032, when the [[County of Vienne]], which had been sold to the [[Archdiocese of Vienne]], was divided between the [[Count of Albon|County of Albon]] and the [[Maurienne]]. Humbert came of noble stock, possibly from [[Saxony]],<ref>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Savoy}}</ref> [[Italy]], [[Burgundy (region)|Burgundy]] or [[Provence]]. He is also called '''Umberto the White-Handed''' ({{lang-fr|Humbert aux Blanches-Mains}}; {{lang-it|Umberto Biancamano}}) reportedly to signify his generosity. However, this posthumously applied title may derive from a textual mistranslation of an early Latin record which actually refers to the walls of his castle, not his hands, as white.<ref>A copyist may have misread the "u" in "mur-" ("wall") as a [[Carolingian minuscule|minuscule]] "a" and the "r" as an "n.". [http://www.regalis.com/reg/savhistory.htm History of House of Savoy]</ref> During the wars between [[Rudolph III of Burgundy]] and the [[Emperor Henry II]], Umberto supported the latter with provisions and soldiers because he was related to the imperial family by marriage. Thus, in 1003, the emperor installed him as the [[Count of Aosta]], a mountainous region then a part of Burgundy but today within Italy, and granted him the northern [[Viennois]] as a reward. Umberto in turn protected the right flank of Henry's army during his subsequent invasion of Italy in 1004. Umberto's lands were essentially autonomous after the death of Henry. Their mountainous inaccessibility and their minor importance lent them to being overlooked and ignored in the power struggles which inevitably followed the death of the emperor. In 1032, Umberto received the Maurienne, his native country, from the [[Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Conrad II]], whom he had helped in his Italian campaigns against [[Aribert, Archbishop of Milan]]. He died at [[Hermillon]], a town in the Maurienne region of present day [[Savoie]], France. == Family == Umberto married Ancilla (Auxilia or Ancilia) of [[Lenzburg]], the daughter of the [[master of ceremonies]] of Burgundy, and had at least four sons: #[[Amadeus I of Savoy|Amadeus I]] (died 1056), Count of Savoy, successor #[[Aymon of Savoy, Bishop of Sion|Aymon]] (died 1054 or 1055), [[Bishop of Sion]] #[[Burchard of Savoy|Burchard]] (died 1068 or 1069), [[Archbishop of Lyon]] #[[Otto of Savoy|Otto]] (died ca. 1057), Count of Savoy, successor of his brother Some authors believe that he had additional sons. == Notes == {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-hou|[[House of Savoy]]||{{circa|980}}||1047 or 1048|name=Umberto the White-Handed}} {{s-reg}} {{s-new|}} {{s-ttl|title=[[County of Savoy|Count of Savoy]] |years=1032â€“1047/1048}} {{s-aft|after=[[Amadeus I of Savoy|Amadeus I]]}} {{s-end}} {{Counts of Savoy}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Umberto I, Count of Savoy | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Umberto the White-Handed; Humbert aux blanches-mains (French); Umberto Biancamano (Italian) | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Italian nobleman; Count of Savoy from 1032 until his death | DATE OF BIRTH = {{circa|980}} | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1047 or 1048 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Hermillon]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Umberto 01, Count of Savoy}} [[Category:980s births]] [[Category:1040s deaths]] [[Category:House of Savoy]]
